title: Wednesday, 31st October 2018
bodyHTML:
11:13 am

Hi. Good morning. It is still morning, right?

DogDay hello all

Manxish Morning persons

Flaneur Re: yesterdays conundrum about underwriters at property auctions and 'why'... it appears they are analogous to 'blood in the water';"Having a mortgage on a vacant property means a month-on-month loss for the owner, so that’s a pretty good indicator on its own. Add to that the fact the property coming to auction (for a fast sale) and you’ve got an ideal vendor profile for an underwriting offer. If the vendor is experiencing financial difficulties as well, and if the place has been on the market for a while, so much the better."http://tinyurl.com/ycajadj8

Why are Wall Street futures up? Because Europe's up.

(@Shinshin: custom. Every single newspaper in the world built its own custom CMS. Because when you're in a go-forward industry with profitability stretching out to the horizon and no risk of obsolescence, why wouldn't you?)

11:21 am
BE11:22am

(@Excel: what does that actually mean?)

Excel Developer haha
Mouselet Good morning assorted capitalist persons. It does focus the mind somewhat to attempt to live off investment income.
BE11:22am

So .......... Computacenter. Doesn't warn and the shares fall nearly 20%.

BE11:23am

Unchanged guidance. Cautious tone from management and third quarter looping some tough comparisons, but hardly a disaster.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Group Q3 revenue -3% Y/Y to £900m, which is the first negative quarter in two years.

Excel Developer @BE: are we speaking in memes now? https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1600/0*6WVGhK2hrNy8oBN4.jpg
BE11:24am

It's a bit of a jumble on a divisional but I'm yet to see anything in the way of significant forecast downgrades.

Tom Dalgleish @Mouse were you not focussed before?
BE11:25am

Here's George O'Connor at Stifel, who references Hallowe'en unfortunately.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Computacenter reports an uneven Q3 which suffered from strong comps, and it says that while its Q4 expectation is for improved growth before acquisitions it is “not to the levels seen in H1”. There is also a smattering of words like “subdued” and “challenged” in the text. While it reiterates FY guidance and signals “all in line”, in these skittish markets expect a volatile response, as sell-side to reach for the red pen. But tarry a little: today could be a great buying opportunity, in our view. In truth, our FY expectations are pretty miserly - we look for H2 Y/Y growth of 1% as today Computacenter report that the nine month YTD figure is 11% - by contrast our FY expectation is 9%. Net/net – ex some of the ugly text, we believe the numbers are trending fine for the year end and the strategic attractions are undiminished. We are therefore relaxed about FY forecasts and make no changes to our recommendation or target price. We acknowledge that the un-even segmental results will cause nerves to twitch, as the cautious are frightened off. It is Halloween – what else would we expect. Whilst we our retain Buy, expect a volatile share price to continue until there is greater clarity as to the trading backdrop. It seems goulish to flag the cheap valuation – 8.8x EV/EBITDA – hardly frightening now is it?

Grouchmonkey All Hallowe'en references should be banned.
BE11:26am

And UBS.

DogDay @Mouse think of this month more as an expensive method for staving off dementia than actual income generation
BE11:27am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Germany grew 2% despite tough comparatives (Q3 17: +26%), while France fell 6% (Q3 17: +34%) and the UK shrank 9% (Q3 17: +8%). In the UK supply chain shrank 12% and Services fell 4% - continuing H1's trend.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No; the outlook is unchanged. Q4 is expected to be grow organically y/y but less than in H1 (+17%). Mgt sees a better pipeline for Professional Services but acknowledges the "Managed Services market is somewhat more challenged which is making growth more difficult" although it expects to continue to take share.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: The market likely anticipated the impact of tough comparatives on growth. Consensus currently implies £1,374m (+17% growth) of sales in Q4, but this includes acquisitions so is unlikely to meaningfully change.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And Credit Suisse.

BE11:28am

The statement acknowledges the more subdued 3Q18
performance, but points to improved growth in 4Q18, helped by a strong pipeline for Professional Services. Consequently, trading remains in line with expectations. We leave forecasts and our Outperform rating unchanged and it is worth noting that this puts Computacenter on track for c15% compound profits growth from FY16-18. The risk to our target price and rating is a macro slowdown that could impact spending decisions in the transactional Technology Sourcing business.

BE11:29am

Which doesn't really answer why they're down, but might answer why they've rallied a bit.

11:29 am
undefined
chad_john Anything on Crawshaw?
chad_john Sad, if not unexpected news
Anton Best research comment of the day (Exane's banking analyst)Let’s talk a little bit about the “better than consensus” charade (which, by the way, drives the share price in the days before and after the results). We all know the legendary ability of the Spanish banks to beat quarterly consensus estimates (note that we highlight the word “quarterly”). In fact, as we so frequently say, no Spanish bank has published a profit warning over the past decade in spite of the biggest collapse in corporate profitability in living memory and the bankruptcy of more than 50% of all the financial institutions operating in the country. Not even once.
Provender Thanks for those BE, analysts less twitchy about CC than I am it seems
BE11:30am

Comments a tad slow this morning.

chad_john GM on the tape, looks a decent beat
Anton When will EU regulators regulate this infomercial (reporting) charade, suffice to look the misterious moves in consensus, Q3 is the best as ahead of reporting you can see 2019 pulled down, so that when reporting takes place 'our guidance for 2019 is in line with consensus'.RIDICULOUS
BE11:31am

@Anton, ta for flagging, though it's a point that's been made many times before.

11:31 am

Dorian Gray More of that type of content please
11:33 am
BE11:33am

So let's move away from the earnings season charade, if only for a moment.

Punter STAN up on Q3 statement, seem absurdly cheap at a third of NAV (nothing new about that) to this stale bull unless they are going to be very seriously clobbered by more fines which are on the way of course. WDIK, any grey please?
BE11:34am

Goldman's had another look at Pets At Home and found the problem that the rest of the market's been talking about for approximately two years.

tonyb @rwl: very true
BE11:34am

As in, vets eat money.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We downgrade Pets at Home to Sell from Neutral as we now expect slower growth in the veterinary segment.

BE11:35am

Increasing wage pressure due to limited availability of veterinary surgeons/nurses in the UK has been a key headwind for Vet practices for the last two years. In our view, this has impacted their profitability leading to an increase in operating loans provided by PAH to practices [c.£32k per practice in FY16 to c.£121k in FY19E or a total of £12.6mn in FY16 to £58mn in FY19E]. We see no abatement in wage cost pressure in the near term, which could lead to a review of new openings as well as closure of underperforming practices. We now model zero net new practice openings for FY20/21E and at this stage we believe PAH’s guidance of 1,000 practices in the long term looks ambitious.

BE11:36am

This leads to a reduction of our FY20/21E PBT by c.3%/7%, respectively (we are now c.3%/7%/9% below Reuters PBT consensus for FY19/20/21E). We also reduce our DCF derived 12m price target to 100p (from 145p earlier) reflecting lower earnings and lower long-term margins given lower Vet practice profitability and lower profit contribution from store. This implies c.15% downside to our price target vs. 25% upside on average for our coverage.

Excel Developer shortage of vet nurses, is that Brexit?

11:47 am
Just Group PLC (JUST:LSE): Last: 90.40, up 0.95 (+1.06%), High: 95.85, Low: 89.10, Volume: 1.79m
TonaldDrump Just Group - cork in the tide I heard on here before?
rwl Have Apple released new kit? mercifully less noise about it this time round.
BE11:48am

We're still waiting on regulatory clarity regarding equity release mortgages, of course, and will be waiting until the middle of next decade for full implementation of the solvency regs.

BE11:48am

In that context, numbers are fine.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Here's RBC.

BE11:49am

30% ahead of consensus is rare. In our view, this highlights the strength of the markets in which Just Group is operating in and the quality of its franchise. The beat was mainly attributable to bulk annuity sales (67% ahead) and Equity Release Mortgages (ERM) (35% ahead). See page 2 for results in pictures.

Record quarter for Equity Release Mortgages. £170m of new ERM business over the quarter, a 24% increase versus the same quarter in 2017. This represents a record quarter for the product, at a time when the expectations were that Just Group would be taking a step back, with consensus expectation of an 8% decrease.

PRA consultation is a back book issue only. Just Group has therefore increased its prices such that its return on capital, assuming the PRA’s most prudent assumptions, is similar to the return on capital prior to the PRA announcement.

TonaldDrump @rwl yep - mostly around Macbooks, bringing back the Macbook mini as well
BE11:49am

Following the PRA announcement in July 2018 that it was consulting on capital requirements for ERM assets, the share price of Just Group has fallen. However, over the last few weeks there have been a number of developments which we believe have been positive: • PRA announcement that it was delaying implementation of any outcome of the ERM consultation until at least 31 December 2019. • Rothesay purchase of historic equity release mortgage book. A buying opportunity. The business is performing extremely well, in spite of the overhanging PRA consultation, in our view. We believe the review will not be as severe as expected and, even if it is, Just Group has many options to strengthen its balance sheet. We continue to see a buying opportunity, supported by a P/E of 3.3x and price which is 39% of historical embedded value of 230p.

Excel Developer I have desktop mini mac, and a very good mug stand it is too

BE12:02pm

We attended Apple’s event in Brooklyn, New York yesterday, where the company announced updates to the existing line up of iPad Pro, MacBook Air and Mac mini devices. Amongst the three, the update to the iPad Pro line up appeared to us to be the most impactful, given the degree of innovation and the ability to drive a refresh cycle of the installed base. In addition to the attention to detail and the focus on customer convenience for all of the products, we think Apple’s focus on the retail experience as a product for the customer was also noteworthy. We believe Apple recognizes the importance of leveraging the rich retail experience to drive customer loyalty to its existing (and future additions to the) ecosystem of products.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

We believe the degree of hardware innovation on the latest iPad Pro and the shorter lifecycle of a tablet relative to a laptop in the installed base makes it more likely to see an upgrade cycle on the iPad installed base, driving greater impact to financials.
